docs.lead_paragraph: Fearful that a court case will lead to the sanctioning of marriages of lesbian and gay couples in Hawaii by the end of 1997, conservatives are campaigning across the nation to insure that the recognition of same-sex marriages will not spread to other states. California is one of 19 states considering measures that would deny government recognition to same-sex marriages performed within the state or elsewhere. South Dakota and Utah have already enacted such laws. And a Defense of Marriage Act is being drafted in the United States Senate.

headline.main: Fearing a Toehold for Gay Marriages, Conservatives Rush to Bar theDoor

docs.lead_paragraph: The New York State Insurance Department yesterday approved a request by Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield to establish two wholly owned for-profit units that could eventually take over most of the troubled health insurer's business. Dr. Michael A. Stocker, chairman of Empire, said the purpose was "to allow us to raise capital" to compete with for-profit managed care companies, which have taken thousands of customers from Empire. The company expects to have the required approval of the state Health Department within a few days.

headline.main: Empire Blue Cross Permitted To Form 2 For-Profit Units

docs.lead_paragraph: The wedge-shaped B-2 Stealth bomber sliced through the brownish-blue California haze. Robert Muse lay back on the hood of the pickup and watched it fly, like a boy gauging the progress of his paper airplane. "Some of me may be in that plane," he said. "My parts. I helped make it fly."

headline.main: More Than Money, They Miss the Pride a Good Job Brought

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Sam M. Gibbons, a 76-year-old Floridian who led efforts for civil rights and open government in the House in the 1960's and became Speaker Newt Gingrich's chief denouncer in the 1990's, announced his retirement today after 34 years in Congress. In 1995, after the Republicans won Congress, he battled them as the Ways and Means Committee's senior Democrat, criticizing Mr. Gingrich and his allies for "baloney," "blackmail," "ineptness," for "whimpering and whining and complaining" and for "behaving like dictators."

headline.main: A Florida Congressman With a Fighting Spirit Will Retire

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton today responded to the anxieties about job security that are rippling through the Republican Presidential race by repackaging his legislative program as a "growth agenda" that will "keep creating jobs and raise incomes" to allow all Americans to compete in the new global economy. Appearing before a cheering, flag-waving crowd crammed into a public works garage in this blue-collar suburb of Detroit, the President listed his economic achievements, noting that his Administration had cut the Federal deficit in half and fostered new jobs in three years.

headline.main: Clinton Urges Action on Bills to Create Jobs and Lift Incomes

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republican leaders said today that they would soon take up a bill intended to expand access to health insurance for millions of Americans, but they intend to add provisions that are likely to generate bitter, prolonged disputes in Congress. The bill, similar to a bipartisan measure pending in the Senate, would guarantee insurance coverage for people moving from one employer-sponsored health plan to another. House Republicans said they wanted to add provisions dealing with medical malpractice, antitrust law, special savings accounts for medical expenses and tax deductions for the health insurance costs of people who are self-employed.

headline.main: G.O.P. Seeks to Expand Access to Health Care, With a Catch

docs.lead_paragraph: A cold wind battered Sheila Steaman's thickly bundled frame as she and a score of co-workers paced endlessly around the plaza in front of an Ontario government office building on Bay Street. "Hands Off Our Pensions," said the sign that twisted in the wind from a string around her neck.

headline.main: With Layoffs Coming, Ontario Workers Strike Over Security

docs.lead_paragraph: Abe Lebewohl, the blustery businessman who transformed a tiny 12-seat restaurant in the East Village into a New York institution called the Second Avenue Deli, was shot and killed in a robbery yesterday morning as he tried to deliver the day's deposits to a nearby bank. Shot once in the head and once in the stomach, Mr. Lebewohl (pronounced LEB-bee-wall), 64, collapsed just six blocks from the restaurant he opened 42 years ago at the corner of East 10th Street and Second Avenue. He was pronounced dead at Bellevue Hospital Center at 9:40 A.M., leaving his family, customers and employees struggling with shock and grief. The police said they had no suspects.

headline.main: Owner of Second Avenue Deli Is Shot and Killed in Robbery

docs.lead_paragraph: Marisa Vural, a 16-year-old high school student, told the Police Commissioner last week that it is easier in many New York neighborhoods for a child to get a gun than a library card.
